ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt the definitions of lying and deception, digital deception, self-deception, Kantian, Platonic and Aristotelian ethics
an insight into the topography of the contemporary discussion on lies and deception.

Critical thinking and analytical skills in the field of philosophy

Organizational skills while writing papers
I learned how to think critically of different forms of lies and deception. I gained a new sense of morality.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Not enough class discussion. A seven-student seminar that lasts two and a half hours needs more actual debate and discussion, even over Zoom.
Strength is the variety of topics covered. Weakness is it can be more organized with fewer written assignments, and classes can be better prepared.
Good discussions, although it would have been good to have more student to student interaction

Very knowledge and passionate professor. 

There should be more discussions, debates and other ways of participation in class

Strengths: Engaging lectures - Prof. Mahon is incredibly knowledgeable and charismatic. The readings were all easy to digest and the authors chosen brought traditional and contemporary points of views.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The readings are fascinating, and although the subject is somewhat dry from a philosophical perspective, it has applications outside of academia. The class itself is boring, which is the biggest problem. Unless you're really interested in the topic, I would not recommend this course.
Yes! If you are interested in ethics and reading so many papers on lies and deception, take this class.
It's a good philosophy course that doesnt get bogged down in semantics and allows you to get to the meat of issues.
Yes, it is a great course for people interested in the philosophy behind deception and lying. Deception plays a huge role in other aspects of society like politics, economics and more.
Definitely! Take the class if you've never gotten into political philosophy (and even if you have).

extras.title:
PHIL S337 01/EP&E S270 01/PLSC S336 01
        Lies and Deception
